2. 
The  proposed  loan  under  the  Countercyclical  Support  Facility  (CSF)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) comes at a critical time for Indonesia. 1  It is designed to maintain the 
momentum  of  its  economic  recovery  and  key  development  efforts  at  a  challenging  time  of 
limited access to global financial markets and the first global recession since World War II. The 
global crisis that intensified after September 2008 has affected the Indonesian economy in four 
related respects: (i) the first-round effects of the global financial crisis had repercussions for the 
domestic financial sector, leading to significant capital flight and exchange rate depreciation in 
the second half of 2008; (ii) the second-round effects of the sharp contraction in global demand 
have hurt the real economy, resulting in a slowdown in economic growth from the fourth quarter 
(Q4) of 2008 until now; (iii) the crisis has had feedbacks to fiscal policy, resulting in a decline in 
tax revenue collection and a wider government budget deficit than initially planned, at a time of 
limited access to global credit markets; and (iv) the economic impact of the global financial crisis 
threatens to undo recent gains in unemployment reduction and poverty reduction.  

Given the second-round effects on the real economy and the emerging fiscal constraint,

The  request  for  financing  stemmed  from  the  Government’s  concerns  about  ensuring 
predictability in its budget financing, given the necessity for a temporary fiscal stimulus in 2009 
and its continuation in 2010. The Government projects gross financing requirements for 2009 at 
$24.5  billion,  including  domestic  and  external  debt  that  matures  in  2009.  Net  financing  (after 
amortization)  for  2009  is  projected  at  $13.6  billion,  of  which  64%  will  need  to  be  raised  in  the 
second half of 2009 (Table 4). Therefore, the INO-CS will provide additional official financing to 
the Government for its larger fiscal stimulus in 2009 and 2010, while the costs of servicing the 
existing debt are also projected to rise. The Government has met the access criteria under the 
Countercyclical Support Facility (Appendix 2). 

4. 
Adverse effects of the global financial crisis. The global financial crisis has adversely 
affected the economy. This impact is manifested in several ways. While domestic consumption 
growth  remained  positive  in  the  first  semester  of  2009,  partly  supported  by  the  Government’s 
effective fiscal stimulus, economic growth weakened to 4.0% in Q2 2009 from 4.4% in Q1, and 
is projected to weaken further in the second semester compared with 6.1% economic growth in 
2008. The  contraction  in  exports  of  27%  in  the  first  semester  of  2009  and  collapse  in  foreign 
direct investment were the key factors behind this sharper than expected economic slowdown.2 
Indonesia is also experiencing temporary fiscal stress because of the economic slowdown. Tax 
revenues declined by 6.2% in the first semester of 2009 over the same period in 2008 and non-
tax revenue (primarily natural resource revenues) declined by 33% over the same period. Debt

5. 
Sound  macroeconomic  management.  The  Government  has  maintained  sound 
macroeconomic  management  and  introduced  preemptive  measures  to  manage  the  increased 
downside  risks  to  the  domestic  financial  sector  and  external  position.  This  is  reflected  in  an

which has resulted in a continuous decline in Indonesia’s public debt–GDP ratio from over 55% 
in 2004 to around 32% at the end of 2008. 
 
6. 
Prudent fiscal response. The Government’s fiscal response to the crisis has been swift 
and  effective.  It  announced  a  countercyclical  spending  program  in  February  2009.  The 
countercyclical program focuses on (i) providing substantial tax cuts to boost household income 
and payroll tax relief to firms operating in labor-intensive industries to protect jobs, (ii) expanding 
capital  expenditure  and  carrying  over  the  2008  infrastructure  projects,  increasing  capital 
maintenance and material spending, and (iii) scaling up key social assistance programs. 
 
7. 
Fiscal  space  and  debt  sustainability.  In  the  context  of  its  debt  level,  the 
countercyclical  spending  program  is  expected  not  to  adversely  affect  debt  sustainability  as  a 
large proportion of the 2009 budget stimulus is temporary in nature. A cross country comparison 
drawing on IMF publications indicates that Indonesia is well placed to sustain its debt at prudent 
levels (Appendix 9 Table A9.2). A more recent IMF country study finds that a primary surplus of 
0.3% of GDP will stabilize debt below 30% of GDP (Appendix 4).  
 
8. 
Donor  coordination.  The  INO-CS  is  an  outcome  of  ADB  policy  dialogue  with  the 
Government  and  coordination  with  development  partners  under  existing  loan  programs  to 
Indonesia, and complements the Development Policy Support Program (DPSP)3 and the Public 
Expenditure Support Facility (PESF).4 The DPSP is a series of five annual, single-tranche loans 
supporting  the  development  policy  agenda  of  the  Government  as  envisioned  in  the  national 
medium-term  development  plan  (RPJM),  and  cofinanced  with  the  World  Bank  and  the 
Government  of  Japan.  The  cluster  aims  to  help  the  Government  achieve  its  medium-term 
growth  and  poverty  reduction  objectives  through  four  core  policy  areas:  (i) macroeconomic 
stability  and  creditworthiness  through  continued  monitoring  of  macroeconomic  indicators; 
(ii) improving the investment climate  through regulatory reforms, tax and customs reforms, and 
strengthening financial sector and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) access to finance; 
(iii) improving public financial management and governance by strengthening budgeting, internal 
control  systems,  transparency  and  procurement,  and  civil  service  reform;  and  (iv)  improving 
delivery  of  public  services  to  the  poor  through  pro-poor  targeting  of  public  programs  and 
strengthening community-driven development.

THE GLOBAL CRISIS AND COUNTRY CONTEXT 

 
A. 

The  Global  Crisis  and  its  Impact  on  the  Indonesian  Economy,  Employment,  and 
Poverty 

 
11. 
The global economic downturn, triggered by the collapse of the US subprime mortgage 
market, has turned into one of the sharpest global economic recessions in modern history. Most 
developed  economies  are  in  deep  recession  in  2009,  and  the  pace  of  economic  growth  in 
developing countries has declined significantly, and in some cases has become negative. The 
latest International Monetary Fund (IMF) projections suggest that economic growth in developed 
countries this year will contract by 3.8%. The volume of world trade is expected to fall by 12.2% 
and foreign direct investment is estimated to fall by about 30% from 2008 levels. The IMF also

First-round  effects  of  the  global  financial  crisis. Spillovers from the global financial 
crisis on the Indonesian financial sector—mainly equity markets and the balance of payments—
were particularly severe in Q4 2008 and more so than in most other regional economies. Equity 
prices  fell  by  50%  and  investors  unbundled  financial  portfolios,  resulting  in  a  decline  of 
$6.5 billion in gross international reserves in Q4 and a 31% depreciation in the rupiah exchange 
rate  from  November  2008  to  February  2009.  Spillovers  to  the  domestic  banking  system  have 
been relatively muted because of the limited exposure to troubled US assets, and low exposure 
to  securitization  and  off-balance  sheet  activities.  The  banking  system  remains  sound,  with  a 
capital asset ratio of 17% and gross nonperforming loans at under 5% as of June 2009.    
  
13. 
However,  the  global  credit  crunch  that  started  in  mid-2008  and  intensified  in  Q4  2008 
hurt  the  Indonesian  economy  by  making  access  to  international  and  domestic  credit  markets 
more  expensive  for  both  the  public  and  private  sectors.  Yields  on  Indonesian  domestic  bonds 
picked  up  since  mid-2008  and  spiked  sharply  in  October  to  as  high  as  20%,  and  spreads 
on  Indonesia’s international bond surged by about 650 basis points (bps) (Figure 1e). This was 
due to a rapid increase in domestic lending of about 30%, in part attributable to the squeeze on 
US  dollar  lines,  and  capital  outflow  and  the  associated  rupiah  exchange  rate  depreciation. 
Elevated  risk  perceptions  about  the  Indonesian  financial  sector  and  economy  have  limited 
Indonesia’s access to international credit markets and raised the cost of borrowing.  
 
14. 
Second-round  effects  of  global  demand  destruction.  Indonesia  is  experiencing  the 
second-round  effects  of  the  global  economic  downturn.  Initially,  it  seemed  the  impact  of  the 
global downturn on Indonesia’s growth conditions was moderate. Economic growth was 5.5% in 
Q4 2008 and a respectable 4.4% in Q1 2009. The latest economic data from the Central Bureau 
of Statistics indicate that the economy is weakening, with growth at 4.0% in Q2 2009 on a year-
on-year  basis.  Moreover,  the  data  show  that  public  expenditure  on  goods  and  services  has 
been  the  main  engine  of  growth  in  the  first  semester  of  2009,  followed  by  household 
consumption, benefiting from one-off election spending and tax cuts implemented as part of the 
stimulus package. Private consumption and investment growth are weakening and exports have 
severely  contracted  (Figure  1a).  As  a  consequence  a  negative  output  gap  (actual  economic 
growth below potential growth) of between 3.0% and 4.0% has emerged in 2009 (Figure 1b). In 
January  2009,  year-on-year  export  values  had  fallen  about  36%.  Although  the  rate  of  decline 
has slowed, export values are still down by 27% in June 2009 on a year-on-year basis. Import 
values have also contracted by 36% in the first half or 2009 because of lower commodity prices 
on resource exports, declining imports of components for the export sector and falling domestic 
demand. Inflow of remittances also declined by 15% from $1.3 billion in Q4 2008 to $1.1 billion 
in Q2 2009 suppressing incomes of poorer families reliant on remittances. ADB staff estimates 
that without the fiscal stimulus package implemented in the first half of 2009, economic growth 
would have been between 2.0% and 3.0% (Appendix 3).

Appropriate  and  responsive  policy. The Government’s macroeconomic policy stance 
to the increased downside risks to the economy from the global crisis has been appropriate and 
responsive.  Stability  is  reflected  in  the  improvement  of  key  macroeconomic  indicators.  On  the 
external  side,  earlier  concerns  about  external  risks  to  the  balance  of  payments  arising  from 
corporate  rollover  and  domestic  resident  capital  outflows  did  not  materialize.  Foreign  reserves 
have  stabilized  since  November  2008  to  $57.9  billion  at  the  end  of  August  2009,  sufficient  to 
cover 6 months of imports. Conventionally, at least 3 months of import coverage is considered a 
sufficient buffer against modest shocks to the balance of payments. On the monetary side, Bank 
Indonesia has broadly operated an appropriate monetary policy stance throughout the crisis. In 
early 2008, it raised interest rates to counter the threat of second-round inflationary pressures 
arising from the surge in global commodity prices. It then shifted to an expansionary monetary 
position  at  the  end  of  2008  to  provide  sufficient  liquidity  to  the  banking  system  against  the 
backdrop  of  rapidly  falling  inflation.  Inflation  fell  to  2.7%  (year-on-year)  in  July  2009,  from  its 
peak of 12.1% in August 2008. Inflation is expected to remain benign for the rest of this year, 
indicative of the slump in domestic economic activity and lower commodity prices.  
 
19. 
The  Government’s  response  to  mitigating  the  risk  of  the  global  financial  crisis  on  the 
Indonesian  economy  was  swift  and  involves  a  number  of  proactive  measures  aimed  at 
reassuring confidence in the domestic financial sector, increasing liquidity in the banking system, 
and strengthening Bank Indonesia’s lender of last resort facility. To maintain the confidence and 
stability of the financial system, the Government (i) issued a financial safety net regulation that 
clearly  establishes  the  roles,  responsibilities,  and  procedures  that  govern  the  actions  and 
responses of Bank Indonesia, the minister of finance, and the Deposit Insurance Corporation in 
the  event  of  the  failure  of  a  financial  institution;  (ii)  strengthened  the  role  of  Bank  Indonesia’s 
lender of last resort facility by allowing banks to borrow in the short term from the central bank, 
backed  up  by  high  quality  assets  such  as  government  bonds  and  Bank  Indonesia  Certificate; 
(iii) increased coverage of the deposit insurance scheme; and (iv) eased liquidity in the banking 
sector  through  monetary  expansion.  Policy  measures  on  the  latter  include  gradually  cutting 
Bank  Indonesia  policy  rates  from  9.5%  in  December  2008  to  6.5%  by  August  2009,  injecting 
rupiah  liquidity  through  repurchase  agreements,  and  reducing  the  reserve  requirement  for 
foreign  currency  deposits.  With  these  proactive  measures  in  place,  indicators  show  signs  of 
improvement.  Bank  liquidity  eased  at  the  end  of  2008,  and  growth  in  bank  lending  started  to 
pick  up  to  about  16%  in  the  first  semester  of  2009  on  a  year-on-year  basis;  the  stock  market 
and the rupiah exchange rate recovered ground since December 2008; and yields on short-term 
domestic  bonds  have  declined,  although  yields  on  medium-  and  longer-term  bonds  remain 
elevated indicating a steeper yield curve compared to prior the global financial crisis.  
 
20. 
To  strengthen  the  external  position,  the  Government  arranged  multilateral  and  bilateral 
swap arrangements to gain ability to call for more foreign reserves when needed. For example, 
Indonesia has access to a $14.6 billion swap facility with the People’s Republic of China. In this 
context  of  slowing  exports  and  waning  market  confidence,  Bank  Indonesia  has  activated  its 
rediscount window for trade receivables and the Government has established an export–import 
financing  agency  that  would  provide  different  trade  finance  products,  including  export  credit 
guarantees, as well as a mandate to support diversification of export markets and SMEs’ access 
to trade finance.

IV. 

THE GOVERNMENT’S COUNTERCYCLICAL FISCAL STIMULUS PROGRAM 

  
The Government’s fiscal policy response to the economic slowdown has been swift and 
24. 
broadly effective. Like most other developing economies, the national government budget does 
not  have  automatic  stabilizers  embedded  on  the  expenditure  side  of  the  budget.  Empirical 
evidence for Indonesia suggests that only two budget items have historically exhibited a relation 
with  the  economic  cycle—government  purchases  of  goods and  services,  and  debt servicing—
and the former has exhibited a distinct pro-cyclical response.6 Debt servicing costs have been 
countercyclical  because  of  the  non-discretionary  nature  of  debt  service.  Government  bond 
premiums  tend  to  rise  during  economic  downturns  along  with  currency  depreciation.  On  the 
revenue  side,  there  appear  to  be  modest  automatic  stabilizers,  i.e.,  tax  revenues  and  non-tax 
revenues fall during downturns. Therefore, with the economy quickly decelerating in Q4 2008, it 
was  necessary  for  the  Government  to  announce  a  national  budget  in  February  2009  that  was 
countercyclical  focusing  on  increasing  priority  capital  spending  and  carrying  over  some 
infrastructure projects from 2008, substantially increasing the materials and capital maintenance 
budget,  expanding  flagship  social  assistance  programs,  and  providing  tax  relief  to  businesses 
and  households.  The  Government  also  announced  additional  stimulus  spending  on 
infrastructure  and  maintenance  in  July  2009  as  part  of  its  fiscal  stimulus  efforts.  Overall,  the 
countercyclical  component  of  the  budget  is  estimated  at  Rp113  trillion.  To  enhance  the 
effectiveness  of  the  countercyclical  spending  program  the  Government  also  introduced  policy 
measures to speed up disbursements of critical public spending.

37. 
The  economic  stimulus  effects.  The  fiscal  stimulus  package  is  projected  at  1.4%  of 
GDP, covering about half of the estimated output gap for 2009 (negative output gap estimated 
at  about  3.0%–4.0%  before  the  stimulus).  On  this  basis,  the  stimulus  appears  to  be  of  an 
appropriate  size.  ADB  assessment  indicates  that  the  fiscal  multiplier  of  the  package  could  be 
1.5%–1.6% of GDP, depending on the type of fiscal stimulus, their multiplier effects, and their 
timing (Appendix 3). For example, the total tax breaks of Rp56 trillion are likely to expand GDP 
by  less  than  this  amount  as  some  proportion  will  be  saved,  while  the  labor-intensive

The Indonesian economy has been adversely affected by the global economic crisis in several ways. 
Government  finances  have  been  more  vulnerable  to  the  deteriorating  external  market  conditions 
because of the country’s large gross financing needs and its reliance on international capital markets 
to finance its budget. The economy has also been under pressure from a sharp decline in trade flows 
and  investment  growth.  Although  the  economy  is  still  resilient,  growth  has  weakened  significantly. 
With  the  external  environment  continuing  to  deteriorate,  economic  growth  is  projected  to  weaken 
further to a level significantly lower than that needed to continue the current pace of poverty reduction. 
Without  strong  domestic  efforts  and  fiscal  stimulus,  poverty  incidence  is  projected  to  increase 
significantly. 
Although  domestic  consumption  remained  robust,  partly  because  of  the  fiscal  stimulus,  economic 
growth weakened significantly to 4% in Q2 2009 and is projected to weaken further to 3.0%–4.0% for 
the rest of the year. 
Exports in June 2009 contracted by 27% and investment growth also weakened significantly to 3.5% 
in Q1 2009 from 13.7% in the same period last year.    
Remittances declined by 15% from $1.3 billion in Q4 2008 to $1.1 billion in Q2 2009. 
To accommodate the fiscal stimulus, the Government increased the budget deficit from 1.0% to 2.5% 
of GDP in the revised budget approved by the Parliament in July 2009. 
Tax revenue has softened considerably because of weakening growth, declining trade flows, and the 
tax-related  stimulus  package.  Actual  tax  revenue  for  the  first  6  months  was  about  43%  of  the  2009 
annual target. 
Spreads surged on dollar bonds to about 1,100 bps in November 2008 from an average of 320 bps in 
the first 6 months of the year. Spreads have gradually declined since April 2009, but remain higher at 
around  430  bps  and  more  volatile  than  those  of  other  countries  in  Southeast  Asia.    Spreads  on 
domestic bonds rose to over 650 bps in 2008.

2. 
Another way of looking at economic performance is the output gap, which measures the 
difference between potential output and actual output in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth. A small output gap suggests that the economy is at its long-run trend or full employment. 
If growth exceeds the potential growth rate (i.e., a positive output gap), it suggests the economy 
risks overheating associated with above-trend inflation. If actual growth is below potential (i.e., a 
negative output gap), this suggests an economic downturn usually associated with below-trend 
inflation.  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  staff  estimates  indicate  that  Indonesia’s  potential 
economic  growth  is  6.0%–6.5%  per  annum.  Staff  estimates  also  indicate  the  emergence  of  a

in  magnitude  to  the  one  that  emerged  in  the  late  1980s  (Figure A3b).  Inflation  is  subdued, 
indicative of weakening aggregate demand and the fall in commodity prices (Figure A3c).

3.

appropriate fiscal expansion will depend on its size relative to the output gap and the multiplier 
(or second-round effects) of the different components of the fiscal stimulus. Empirical evidence 
for  other  countries  indicates  that  infrastructure  spending  has  the  largest  multiplier  effects, 
followed  by  cash  transfers  to  poor  families;  tax  breaks  have  the  lowest  multiplier  effects 
(generally less than 1) as some proportion will be saved.

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
Indonesia’s  National  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (NPRS)  has  five  basic  strategies  for  poverty  reduction:  (i)  broadening 
opportunities,  (ii)  empowering  community  institutions,  (iii)  increasing  capacity,  (iv)  providing  social  protection,  and 
(v) promoting global partnerships. The NPRS is to be implemented through macroeconomic strategy and policies for fulfilling 
basic  rights,  promoting  gender  justice  and  equality,  and  regional  development.  It  considers  macroeconomic  policies  as  the 
foundation  for  reducing  poverty  through  a  supportive  business  environment  and  broad  opportunities  for  increasing  the 
capability  of  the  poor  through  four  related  objectives:  (i)  create  macroeconomic  stability,  (ii)  promote  economic  growth, 
(iii) increase  opportunities  for  employment  and  entrepreneurship,  and  (iv)  reduce  inequalities  between  regions.  The 
Government’s  medium-term  national  development  plan  (RPJM)  includes  the  main  tenets  of  the  previous  draft  NPRS  and 
incorporates  the  eight  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs). This  provides  an  overarching  framework  that  places  human 
development and poverty reduction at the center of the development agenda. 
 
The  country  poverty  assessmenta  and  country  poverty  partnership  agreementb  consider  macroeconomic  stability  as  a 
fundamental underpinning to poverty reduction. The poverty agreement also calls for expanding and improving such key basic 
services  as  health,  education,  water  supply,  and  sanitation  through  public–private  partnerships;  and  points  out  the  need  to 
expand the system of social protection. The Countercyclical Support Facility (CSF) provides support to government measures 
aimed at mitigating the impact of the global financial crisis and keeping the country on track to meet MDG targets. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General intervention 
1. Key Issues  
 
The current global financial crisis is expected to lead to reduced economic growth, retrenchments, move to informal sectors, 
and  decreased  real  wages  and  living  standards  for  a  significant  portion  of  the  population. The  economy  is  slowing  down  in 
2009, with growth projections ranging from 3.0% to 4%. Exports in June declined by 27% on a year-on-year basis, suggesting 
that  the  lower  end  of  projections  is  an  increasingly  likely  outcome  for  2009.  ADB  staff  estimates  that  without  the  fiscal 
stimulus, poverty could rise by 3 to 4 million person or 1 to 2 percentage points of the population.  
 
2. Design Features  
 
Indonesia Countercyclical Support (INO-CS) supports government efforts to mitigate the effects of the crisis by supporting a 
stimulus package, cash transfer programs for the poor, and maintaining critical spending on social sectors and infrastructure. 
 
C. Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
The recent fall in inflation and thus food prices has benefited the poor, which spend a larger proportion of their budget on food 
than the average household. The poverty rate declined to 14.2% in early 2009 from 14.4% in early 2008, showing the effects 
of the good rice harvest, stability in food and fuel prices, and the impact of the unconditional cash transfer (UCT) program to 
the  poor  and  near  poor  that  was  implemented  in  2008–2009.  The  country  defines  poverty  based  on  a  consumption  bundle 
that consists of food items (to satisfy 2,100 calories) and basic non-food items determined by the pattern of consumption of 
reference  households  near  the  poverty  line.  As  in  most  developing  economies,  poverty  is  mostly  a  rural  phenomenon  in 
Indonesia.  
 
The  unemployment  rate  decreased  to  8.14%  in  February  2009  from  8.46%  in  February  2008.However,  stress  in  the  labor 
market is showing up in a surge in people entering the informal sector in 2009, with new hire in the formal sector declining to 
400.000  from  about  1.8  million  in  2008.  Public  services  also  remain  inadequate  in  Indonesia  from  a  middle-income  country 
standard. High malnutrition and maternal mortality rates, inadequate access to safe water and sanitation, and poor education 
outcomes  are  other  dimensions  of  poverty.  Access  to  rural  infrastructure  is  also  limited.  Inequality  has  increased  over  time

3. 
Composition  of  stimulus.  Fiscal  stimulus  packages  are  typically  comprised  of  (i)  tax-
